title: Cartel clock
description: Cartel clock mounted in a gilded bronze case. On a large S-shaped volute, lower left of the round dial, sits the goddess Diana on the clouds with arms spread toward the slumbering Endymion, lying on a smaller volute lower right, with shepherd's staff in hand and flanked by his dog. Above the dial, Cupid watches from the clouds with bow and arrow in his hands. Upper left of the dial is a wall with shell motif and cornice; finished with flower, leaf and volute motifs.
character: Someone who wants everything to be perfect and demands the highest standards possible. And wants to be like other clocks.
maker: Jacques Caffieri, Julien Le Roy, Antoine-Nicolas Martinière

title: Gaming table
description: Folding gaming table of walnut with octagonal top of oak, covered with embroidery in gros- and petit-point of multicolored wool and silk. The leg is baluster-shaped, has a hexagonal shaft and three volute feet. The tapestry of the top displays the Judgment of Paris, framed by Louis XIV ornament.

title: Mantle Clock
description: Mantle clock of gilded and patinated bronze and mahogany. The clock consists of a wooden box for the clock case, with gilded bronze inserts. On top of this is the gilded clock, with a patinated bronze female figure leaning on a stack of books, stacked on top of the clock. The figure holds a roll of paper in her hand, symbolizing Study or Science. On the clock, beneath the dial, Venus is depicted teaching Cupid to read. The frieze (the frontmost bronze instert into the clock case), has child figures representing the Arts and Sciences. The Clock is signed on back plate: 'VULLIAMY/LONDON/NO. 492' and stamped on front plate: 492. The (now missing) pendulum was also numbered 492. On the spines of two books the inscriptions: PHYS/TOM.3 and ASTRO/TOMI. On the back of two of the bronze plates from which the case is assembled, partially legible inscription in Latin, including the words: VS AMOR PIGNOR A DIEI EDUCAVIT VTIAM PAREM HOS VTRIVSQ. The clockwork was replaced in 1811 in London by Benjamin Lewis Vulliamy.

title: Oak Cabinet
description: Cabinet of oak, veneered with walnut and burl walnut, consisting of an upper and lower case, both with strongly curved surfaces and S-shaped curves in horizontal cross-section. Round corner posts; wavy bottom, middle and top moldings. The carved ornaments consist of rocailles and plant motifs. The cabinet stands on so-called foaming feet. The hinges and keyholes are concealed by flower branches growing over them. All of this makes the entire piece of furniture work as one ornamental form.

title: Rosewood chair
description: Chair of rosewood with upholstered seat, with hanging lambrequins with fringe, with border and diamond work and a coat of arms on top, executed in needlework. The back space, between two fluted columns with Ionic capitals and consoles, connected by an arch with a mask, is filled with openwork grotesques. On top is a straight molding with two averted griffins between which is a coat of arms (of the Van Voorst van Beest and Ruys families). Decorated legs and lower rails.

title: Chest of painted poplar wood
description: Chest of painted poplar wood, resting on the scalloped corner pieces of the lower sill. The front is quarter-round, alternately painted with heraldic figures placed within squares, interrupted left and right by a wreath of leaves with flowers, within which is a coat of arms with ladder and crowned by four fleurs-de-lis. The sides also display heraldic figures and bear iron handles.

title: Decorated Painter's Box
description: Oak painter's box painted black, marbled on the inside or covered with red cloth and painted on the outside with scenes including two cavalry battles, a grisaille with winter landscape with hunters, a water landscape with duck decoy and ducks, and two village views; on the inside of the lid a shepherd scene. The box contains three drawers with pull rings, of which the top one does not occupy the full width, with 34 painting supplies; under the lid eight compartments of various sizes.
maker: Attributed to Anthonie Jansz. van der Croos, Jan Martszen de Jonge

title: Chair with diagonally placed front legs
description: Chair of walnut, upholstered with bronze-colored pressed plush with floral pattern. The chair has diagonally placed front legs in the form of broken S-volutes and rest on lion claws grasping balls. The X-shaped cross has broken S-volutes, as does the front rail. A knob stands at the intersection. The high, openwork back also displays S-volutes. The elongated center piece is decorated with circle and rosette in the middle and above and below with acanthus leaf and rosettes.

title: Tortoiseshell Cabinet
description: Cabinet veneered with marquetry of various wood types and partially green-colored ivory on a tortoise shell base. The cabinet with drawers rests on six legs. The fronts of the drawers and the sides and top of the cabinet display flower branches; on the oval center panels of the sides, flower vases on plinths are depicted.

title: Sideboard
description: Sideboard of coromandel wood consisting of a lower section with slanted sides, a receding middle section and a top. The lower section is divided into five sections separated by posts with carved half-columns. The three middle parts each contain two doors with a drawer above them. The other two parts form the beveled corners and contain a panel with a drawer above. The doors consist of panels carved with crowned coats of arms and two confronting lions amid foliage. Each coat of arms is different and is inlaid with palmwood. The panels on the beveled corners contain carved flower branches. The drawers are inlaid with ivory and palmwood and contain, like the doors, copper fittings consisting of keyplates and handles in the form of masks and predators. In the receding middle section are four display cases separated by posts with carved half-columns and figures. Below the display cases is a wide openwork rail with inlaid medallions. A forward-curved wall forms the transition from the display cases to the top. The top contains three openwork rails, two above each other and one receding above them. The two rails above each other are divided by nine posts, seven of which are crowned with carved figures. These alternately end at the bottom in lion heads or two intertwined figures. The other two posts, located on either side of the middle post, are crowned with a carved coat of arms and end at the bottom in a bull's head.
maker: Carel Adolph Lion Cachet, Kunsthandel E.J. van Wisselingh
